pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:0.5: 69. The training rule on low seats
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six were sitting on low seats while giving teachings to people sitting on high seats.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.3: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.4: “How could the monks from the group of six sit on low seats while giving teachings to people sitting on high seats?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.5: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.8: Foolish men, how can you sit on low seats while giving teachings to people sitting on high seats?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.9: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.11: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.12: “At one time in Bārāṇasī, monks, there was a low-caste man whose wife became pregnant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.16: ‘There are no mangoes; it’s the wrong season.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.17: ‘If I don’t get any, I will die.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.18: At that time the king had a mango tree that was always bearing fruit.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.19: Then that low-caste man went to that mango tree, climbed it, and hid himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.20: Just then the king and his brahmin counsellor went to that same mango tree. The king then sat on a high seat while learning mantras.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.22: ‘How wrong-headed this king is, in that he sits on a high seat while learning mantras.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.23: And the brahmin is wrong-headed too, in that he sits on a low seat while teaching the mantras to one sitting on a high seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.24: And I’m wrong-headed too, in that I steal mangoes from the king because of a woman.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.26: And he fell out of the tree right there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.29: Not he who teaches the mantras,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.32: With a curry of pure meat:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.33: Therefore I’m not practicing the Teaching,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.34: The Teaching praised by the Noble Ones.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.34a: The low-caste man replies in turn:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.35: ‘A curse it is the gaining of wealth,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.36: And the gaining of fame, too, brahmin;
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.37: These things come with a low rebirth,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.40: Other beings will do the cooking;
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.42: Because then you will break like a jar.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.43: Even at that time, monks, the teaching of mantras while sitting on a low seat to someone sitting on a high seat was displeasing to me. How then could the giving of teachings in this way not be displeasing now?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.44: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.45: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.46: ‘“I will not give teachings while sitting on a low seat to anyone sitting on a high seat who is not sick,” this is how you should train.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.47: One should not give teachings while sitting on a low seat to anyone sitting on a high seat who is not sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.48: If a monk out of disrespect gives teachings while sitting on a low seat to someone sitting on a high seat, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.50: if it is unintentional; if he is not mindful; if he does not know; if he is sick; if there are dangers; if he is insane;
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.51: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk69:1.52: The ninth training rule is finished.
